(This was copied from a post by Dr Nihal 
Ranjan )

Pregnant and Obstetricised Senior Physician Dr. SHO Gamini Wimalaratne who works in Kurunegala Hospital

Although there were many things about this incident, I tried to keep quiet in the current situation. But it is possible that something should be said because some of the responsible people are certain that certain unreliable statements are being issued.
First of all, I am not so happy with the physician involved in the incident. I know him but there is no relationship with us.
I am a long-term medical practitioner in the Kurunegala Teaching Hospital and I am a veterinarian in the nursery and obstetrics division. Although I have not counted correctly, I have done more than 4,000 Caesareans. A doctor and a well equipped nurse are in the care of a physician who performs a cesarean surgery. They all become aware of all the steps in the operation. They can not even tighten their eyes and can not even twist them. Because the equipment, the threads, etc., should be supplied by a support nurse. Fallopian tubes are not very tiny microscopic organs. If they clamp from a device, they show up for those in close proximity. But to say that others can do the same thing. That is, they can squeeze through their finger tips. These can make some damage. But it is practically possible to regain the tubes. Because of this, I feel that this 4000 storytelling story is not a reality. I recall the prevalence of kidney failure shortly before surgery.
I'm looking at another idea. That's about the ability to damage the tubes in poorly tested or surgical procedures. As such, tests (like HSGs) do not enter the tube, something like this can not be done. Cardiac surgery is usually performed by a VOG but not by a SHO.
Finally, it should be said. If the medical doctor can not do such a thing without the support of his assistants, if any.
As I well know, such shameless supporters or nurse officers are in the Kurunegala hospital.
Therefore, I kindly state that the social media should act with care and responsibility when presenting such statements.

(This was copied from a post by Dr Nihal Ranjan)
